context: In contrast to the hazy, relatively featureless atmosphere of Uranus, Neptune's atmosphere has active and visible weather patterns. For example, at the time of the <b5_0>Voyager 2<b5_0/> flyby in <b6_0>1989<b6_0/>, the planet's southern hemisphere had a <a0_0>Great Dark Spot<a0_0/> comparable to the <b10_0>Great Red Spot<b10_0/> on Jupiter. These weather patterns are driven by the strongest <a1_0><b8_0><b11_0>sustained winds<b11_0/><b8_0/><a1_0/> of any planet in the Solar System, with recorded wind speeds as high as <a2_0><b7_0><b12_0>2,100 kilometres per hour<b12_0/><b7_0/><a2_0/> (580 m/s; 1,300 mph). Because of its great distance from the Sun, Neptune's outer atmosphere is one of the coldest places in the Solar System, with temperatures at its cloud tops approaching <a3_0><b13_0>55 K<b13_0/> (−218 °C).<a3_0/> Temperatures at the planet's centre are approximately <a4_0><b14_0>5,400 K (5,100 °C)<b14_0/><a4_0/>. Neptune has a faint and <b9_0>fragmented ring system<b9_0/> (labelled "arcs"), which was first detected during the 1960s and confirmed by Voyager 2.
